The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent pain in her neck, right shoulder, and arm, as well as a tingling sensation in her right hand. She first noticed her symptoms after she got off a rollercoaster ride 2 months ago. Physical examination shows weakness when extending the right wrist against resistance. An MRI of the head and neck is shown. This patient's condition is most likely the result of nerve root compression by a structure derived from which of the following embryologic layers?
(A) Neural crest (B) Notochord (C) Neural tube (D) Surface ectoderm
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent pain in her neck, right shoulder, and arm, as well as a tingling sensation in her right hand. She first noticed her symptoms after she got off a rollercoaster ride 2 months ago. Physical examination shows weakness when extending the right wrist against resistance. An MRI of the head and neck is shown. This patient's condition is most likely the result of nerve root compression by a structure derived from which of the following embryologic layers?
options: (A) Neural crest (B) Notochord (C) Neural tube (D) Surface ectoderm
outputs:
The patient has intermittent pain in her neck, right shoulder, and arm, as well as a tingling sensation in her right hand. She first noticed her symptoms after she got off a rollercoaster ride 2 months ago. Physical examination shows weakness when extending the right wrist against resistance. The MRI of the head and neck shows a mass that is compressing the nerve root. The mass is likely to be a meningioma, which is a tumor that arises from the meninges, which are derived from the neural crest. The answer is (A).

Q: A 75-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of severe pain in his right knee. He has a history of osteoarthritis. He appears uncomfortable and has a temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F). Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of the right knee. There is a large effusion. The patient is unable to bear weight on the right leg. The radiograph of the knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Acute osteoarthritis (B) Acute bursitis (C) Acute cellulitis (D) Acute deep venous thrombosis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of osteoarthritis and is presenting with the sudden onset of severe pain in his right knee, swelling and erythema of the right knee, and a large effusion. He is unable to bear weight on the right leg. The radiograph of the knee shows evidence of a joint effusion. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with acute bursitis. The answer is (B).

Q: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of left-sided chest pain. She has a history of smoking and hypertension. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a blood pressure cuff on her left arm. There is a 2 x 2 cm (0.8 x 0.8 in) patch of ecchymosis over the medial aspect of her left arm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (B) Administer intravenous heparin (C) Perform an electrocardiogram (D) Perform an arteriogram
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of smoking and hypertension. She is presenting with sudden onset of left-sided chest pain. Her blood pressure is elevated. Physical examination shows a blood pressure cuff on her left arm. There is a 2 x 2 cm (0.8 x 0.8 in) patch of ecchymosis over the medial aspect of her left arm. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a probable left-sided pulmonary embolism. The next step in management would be to perform an electrocardiogram to rule out a myocardial infarction. The answer is (C).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 32-year-old female is brought to the emergency room by her friend for acute onset abdominal pain. She states that she was in a kickboxing class when she suddenly developed left-sided abdominal pain. Her past medical history is significant for chlamydia. She is currently sexually active and does not use contraception. Her menstrual periods occur regularly every 30 days. Her last menstrual period ended 2 days ago. The patient’s temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 14/min with an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. On physical exam, there is left-sided, lower abdominal tenderness and guarding. Pelvic examination is notable for clear mucous in the vaginal introitus and tenderness of the left adnexa. A pelvic ultrasound with Doppler reveals a large amount of fluid in the rectouterine pouch. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Ectopic pregnancy (B) Ovarian torsion (C) Pelvic inflammatory disease (D) Ruptured ovarian cyst
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 32-year-old female is brought to the emergency room by her friend for acute onset abdominal pain. She states that she was in a kickboxing class when she suddenly developed left-sided abdominal pain. Her past medical history is significant for chlamydia. She is currently sexually active and does not use contraception. Her menstrual periods occur regularly every 30 days. Her last menstrual period ended 2 days ago. The patient’s temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 14/min with an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. On physical exam, there is left-sided, lower abdominal tenderness and guarding. Pelvic examination is notable for clear mucous in the vaginal introitus and tenderness of the left adnexa. A pelvic ultrasound with Doppler reveals a large amount of fluid in the rectouterine pouch. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: (A) Ectopic pregnancy (B) Ovarian torsion (C) Pelvic inflammatory disease (D) Ruptured ovarian cyst
outputs:
The patient is a 32-year-old female with acute onset abdominal pain. She is sexually active and does not use contraception. Her menstrual periods occur regularly every 30 days, and her last menstrual period ended 2 days ago. She has a history of chlamydia. The patient's pelvic examination shows clear mucous in the vaginal introitus and tenderness of the left adnexa. A pelvic ultrasound with Doppler reveals a large amount of fluid in the rectouterine pouch. The patient's symptoms and examination findings are consistent with pelvic inflammatory disease. The most likely diagnosis is (C) Pelvic inflammatory disease.

Q: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She has a history of hypertension and migraines. She has been compliant with her medications. She has no history of substance abuse or recent travel. She is currently menstruating. Her temperature is 99.4°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 20/min. On physical exam, she appears ill and uncomfortable. There is no evidence of focal neurological deficits or meningism. Her headache is generalized and severe. She has not had any recent vaccinations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intramuscular sumatriptan (B) Order a non-contrast head CT (C) Order a lumbar puncture (D) Administer intravenous metoclopramide
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and migraines. She has been compliant with her medications. She has no history of substance abuse or recent travel. She is currently menstruating. Her symptoms and examination findings are consistent with a migraine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intramuscular sumatriptan. The answer is (A).

Q: A 45-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension comes to the clinic because of a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. He denies any recent trauma or injury. He appears uncomfortable. The knee is swollen and tender to palpation. The patient's blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 100/min. There is no pedal edema. The patient's urinalysis shows 2+ protein, 1+ blood, and numerous red blood cells. The patient's creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an MRI of the knee (B) Order an ultrasound of the knee (C) Administer intravenous furosemide (D) Administer intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of smoking and hypertension. He has a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain without any recent trauma or injury. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 100/min. There is no pedal edema. The patient's urinalysis shows 2+ protein, 1+ blood, and numerous red blood cells. The patient's creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL. The patient's symptoms and examination findings are consistent with acute nephritic syndrome. The most appropriate next step in management is to order an MRI of the knee. The answer is (A).

Q: A 63-year-old man from the countryside presents with leg swelling and right upper abdominal tenderness. He reports a history of myocardial infarction 4 years ago, but he has no supporting documentation. At the moment, his only medication is aspirin. He also stated that he used to have ‘high blood sugars’ when checked in the hospital 4 years ago, but he did not follow up regarding this issue. He works as a farmer and noticed that it became much harder for him to work in the last few days because of fatigue and syncope. He has a 24-pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol occasionally. The vital signs include: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉). On physical examination, the patient is pale and acrocyanotic. There is a visible jugular vein distention and bilateral lower leg pitting edema. The pulmonary auscultation is significant for occasional bilateral wheezes. Cardiac auscultation is significant for a decreased S1, S3 gallop, and grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space. Abdominal percussion and palpation are suggestive of ascites. The hepatic margin is 3 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is positive. Which of the following is the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram?
(A) Left ventricular ejection fraction of 41% (B) Increased peak tricuspid regurgitation (C) Hypokinetic wall of the left ventricle (D) Abnormal left ventricular relaxation
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 63-year-old man from the countryside presents with leg swelling and right upper abdominal tenderness. He reports a history of myocardial infarction 4 years ago, but he has no supporting documentation. At the moment, his only medication is aspirin. He also stated that he used to have ‘high blood sugars’ when checked in the hospital 4 years ago, but he did not follow up regarding this issue. He works as a farmer and noticed that it became much harder for him to work in the last few days because of fatigue and syncope. He has a 24-pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol occasionally. The vital signs include: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉). On physical examination, the patient is pale and acrocyanotic. There is a visible jugular vein distention and bilateral lower leg pitting edema. The pulmonary auscultation is significant for occasional bilateral wheezes. Cardiac auscultation is significant for a decreased S1, S3 gallop, and grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space. Abdominal percussion and palpation are suggestive of ascites. The hepatic margin is 3 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is positive. Which of the following is the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram?
options: (A) Left ventricular ejection fraction of 41% (B) Increased peak tricuspid regurgitation (C) Hypokinetic wall of the left ventricle (D) Abnormal left ventricular relaxation
outputs:
The patient has a history of myocardial infarction 4 years ago. He has been experiencing leg swelling and right upper abdominal tenderness. He also has a history of smoking and alcohol consumption. The patient's vital signs show hypertension and tachycardia. Physical examination shows pale and acrocyanotic skin, jugular vein distention, bilateral lower leg pitting edema, occasional bilateral wheezes, decreased S1, S3 gallop, and grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space. Abdominal percussion and palpation suggest ascites, and the hepatic margin is 3 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is positive. The patient's symptoms and physical examination are consistent with congestive heart failure. The most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram is (A) Left ventricular ejection fraction of 41%.

1. (A) Eplerenone 
2. (B) Perform gonioscopy 
3. (A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks
4. (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test 
5. (B) Hepatitis C serology
6. (D) Abnormal left ventricular relaxation

The following are multiple choice questions (with answers) about professional medicine.

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty discarding items in her home. She says that the accumulation of things in her kitchen and dining room makes regular use of these spaces incredibly difficult. Her behavior started when she was in high school. She feels anxious when she tries to discard her possessions and her husband tries to clean and organize the home. This behavior frustrates her because most of the items she saves have little emotional or monetary value. She reports that there has been no improvement despite attending cognitive behavioral therapy sessions for the past 6 months. She now feels that her behavior is “taking over” her life. She does not drink, smoke, or use illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/80 mm Hg. On mental status examination, she is calm, alert, and oriented to person, place, and time. Her mood is depressed; her speech is organized, logical, and coherent; and there are no psychotic symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Fluoxetine (B) Lamotrigine (C) Buspirone (D) Methylphenidate
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty discarding items in her home. She says that the accumulation of things in her kitchen and dining room makes regular use of these spaces incredibly difficult. Her behavior started when she was in high school. She feels anxious when she tries to discard her possessions and her husband tries to clean and organize the home. This behavior frustrates her because most of the items she saves have little emotional or monetary value. She does not drink, smoke, or use illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/80 mm Hg. On mental status examination, she is calm, alert, and oriented to person, place, and time. Her mood is depressed; her speech is organized, logical, and coherent; and there are no psychotic symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: (A) Fluoxetine (B) Lamotrigine (C) Buspirone (D) Methylphenidate
outputs:
The patient has difficulty discarding items in her home and feels anxious when she tries to discard her possessions. She has been attending cognitive behavioral therapy sessions for the past 6 months, but there has been no improvement. She now feels that her behavior is “taking over” her life. She has no history of substance abuse and is not currently taking any medications. The patient's symptoms are consistent with hoarding disorder. The most appropriate next step in management would be to initiate a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) such as fluoxetine, which has been shown to be effective in the treatment of hoarding disorder. The answer is (A).

Q: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and morning headaches. She also reports difficulty with bending or stooping. She has been taking estrogen and progesterone for menopausal symptoms. She is a former smoker, having quit 5 years ago. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a prominent thoracic kyphosis and forward flexion of the thoracic spine. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A chest x-ray shows a prominent thoracic kyphosis and a 1-cm rounded opacity in the right midlung field. A CT scan of the chest shows a 1.5-cm, well-circumscribed, spiculated mass in the right midlung field. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Bronchoscopy (B) Needle aspiration biopsy (C) Excisional biopsy (D) Lobectomy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-year history of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and morning headaches. She also reports difficulty with bending or stooping. She has a history of smoking and is taking estrogen and progesterone for menopausal symptoms. Physical examination shows a prominent thoracic kyphosis and forward flexion of the thoracic spine. A chest x-ray and CT scan of the chest show a 1.5-cm, well-circumscribed, spiculated mass in the right midlung field. These findings are consistent with a lung cancer diagnosis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a bronchoscopy to obtain a tissue sample for further evaluation and diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden hearing loss in his right ear. He also reports a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He has no history of previous hearing loss or ear trauma. He recently started taking furosemide for hypertension. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows Weber Class III/IV hearing loss in the right ear and Weber Class I hearing loss in the left ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer furosemide (B) Administer naloxone (C) Administer dexamethasone (D) Administer aspirin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden hearing loss in his right ear, along with a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He has no history of previous hearing loss or ear trauma. He recently started taking furosemide for hypertension. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows Weber Class III/IV hearing loss in the right ear and Weber Class I hearing loss in the left ear. The patient's symptoms are consistent with sudden sensorineural hearing loss (SSNHL), which is a medical emergency that requires prompt treatment. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer dexamethasone, as it has been shown to improve hearing recovery in patients with SSNHL. The answer is (C).

Q: A 59-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider complaining of diffuse bodily aches. She reports a 3-month history of gradually worsening pain in her shoulders and hips that is worse in her right hip. She has a history of hypertension and recurrent renal stones for which she takes lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. She was admitted to the hospital earlier in the year after falling in her front yard and sustaining a distal radius fracture and vertebral compression fracture. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 20/min. On exam, she is well-appearing with mild tenderness to palpation in her shoulders and hips. She has mild pain with hip flexion and shoulder abduction. She has full range of motion in her bilateral upper and lower extremities. Serum findings are notable for the following:

Serum:
Na+: 141 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.8 mEq/L
HCO3-: 22 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen: 17 mg/dL
Glucose: 110 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.12 mg/dL
Ca2+: 11.2 mg/dL
Phosphate: 2.3 mg/dL
Mg2+: 1.9 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 120 U/L

A radiograph of this patient’s right hip would most likely reveal which of the following?
(A) Expansile lytic lesion with thin sclerotic margins (B) Medullary bone destruction with elevated periosteum from cortical bone (C) Poorly marginated lesion extending into adjacent soft tissue (D) Well-defined cystic lesion with peritrabecular fibrosis
A: Let's think step by step.
question:
Q: A 59-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider complaining of diffuse bodily aches. She reports a 3-month history of gradually worsening pain in her shoulders and hips that is worse in her right hip. She has a history of hypertension and recurrent renal stones for which she takes lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. She was admitted to the hospital earlier in the year after falling in her front yard and sustaining a distal radius fracture and vertebral compression fracture. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 20/min. On exam, she is well-appearing with mild tenderness to palpation in her shoulders and hips. She has mild pain with hip flexion and shoulder abduction. She has full range of motion in her bilateral upper and lower extremities. Serum findings are notable for the following:

Serum:
Na+: 141 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.8 mEq/L
HCO3-: 22 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen: 17 mg/dL
Glucose: 110 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.12 mg/dL
Ca2+: 11.2 mg/dL
Phosphate: 2.3 mg/dL
Mg2+: 1.9 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 120 U/L

A radiograph of this patient’s right hip would most likely reveal which of the following?
options: (A) Expansile lytic lesion with thin sclerotic margins (B) Medullary bone destruction with elevated periosteum from cortical bone (C) Poorly marginated lesion extending into adjacent soft tissue (D) Well-defined cystic lesion with peritrabecular fibrosis
outputs:
The patient has a history of hypertension and recurrent renal stones. She has a recent history of falling and sustaining a distal radius fracture and vertebral compression fracture. She is complaining of diffuse bodily aches, specifically in her shoulders and hips. The patient's blood chemistry is notable for a low serum potassium level (K+: 4.8 mEq/L). This, along with the patient's history of hypertension, suggests the possibility of hyperaldosteronism. The patient's radiograph of the right hip would most likely reveal a poorly marginated lesion extending into adjacent soft tissue, which is consistent with a metastatic lesion. The answer is (C).

Q: A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of sudden-onset severe headache, blurred vision, and vomiting. She has no significant medical history. She is currently taking no medications. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 158/108 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A non-contrast head CT shows a 5-mm left parietal intracerebral hemorrhage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous rt-PA (B) Administer intravenous metoclopramide (C) Administer intravenous hydralazine (D) Perform lumbar puncture
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a sudden-onset severe headache, blurred vision, and vomiting. The non-contrast head CT shows a 5-mm left parietal intracerebral hemorrhage. The patient has no significant medical history. The patient's symptoms are consistent with a ruptured aneurysm. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer intravenous rt-PA, a thrombolytic agent, to dissolve the blood clot and prevent further damage. The answer is (A).

Q: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive difficulty with walking and a 2-month history of fever, chills, and night sweats. He has a history of alcohol abuse and smoking. He appears thin and has a temperature of 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse of 110/min, respirations of 20/min, and blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows marked tenderness to palpation over the thoracic and lumbar spine. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 11.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4,500/mm3, and platelet count is 198,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The patient's serum ANA is positive. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with a pronounced polyclonal IgM band. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and smoking. He has a 6-month history of progressive difficulty with walking, fever, chills, and night sweats. He has a temperature of 38.3°C (100.9°F), which is consistent with a fever. His urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. His serum ANA is positive, which suggests the presence of an autoimmune disorder. His serum complement levels are decreased. The following are multiple choice questions (with answers) about professional medicine.

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 20-year-old woman is brought in for a psychiatric consultation by her mother who is concerned because of her daughter’s recent bizarre behavior. The patient’s father died from lung cancer 1 week ago. Though this has been stressful for the whole family, the daughter has been hearing voices and having intrusive thoughts ever since. These voices have conversations about her and how she should have been the one to die and they encourage her to kill herself. She has not been able to concentrate at work or at school. She has no other history of medical or psychiatric illness. She denies recent use of any medication. Today, her heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F). On physical exam, she appears gaunt and anxious. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. CMP, CBC, and TSH are normal. A urine toxicology test is negative. What is the patient’s most likely diagnosis?
(A) Brief psychotic disorder (B) Adjustment disorder (C) Schizophrenia (D) Bereavement
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 20-year-old woman is brought in for a psychiatric consultation by her mother who is concerned because of her daughter’s recent bizarre behavior. outputs:

She does not have a history of medical or psychiatric illness and has not been using any medication. Her physical examination and laboratory test results are normal. The patient's symptoms are consistent with brief psychotic disorder, which is a short-term episode of psychosis that can be triggered by a stressful event. The answer is (A).

Q: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of severe headache, blurred vision, and confusion. He is currently being treated for hypertension with hydrochlorothiazide. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/200 in the right eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the left eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a severe headache, blurred vision, and confusion. He is currently being treated for hypertension with hydrochlorothiazide. He appears uncomfortable. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The patient has symptoms consistent with acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. The most appropriate next step in management is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) Ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but is not widely available. (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. (C) Fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy. (D) Topical steroids are not relevant; the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine, or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform gonioscopy. The answer is (B).

Q: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and a sensation that her heart was racing for the past 3 days. She adds that she has lost weight over the last 7 weeks, despite a good appetite, and is anxious most of the time with difficulty sleeping at night. She has smoked 10 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years. Her blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg, temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and pulse is irregular with a rate of 140–150/min. On physical examination she is thin, frail, and appears anxious. Her palms are sweaty and there are fine tremors on extension of both hands. She has a palpable smooth thyroid mass. Examination of the eyes reveals bilateral exophthalmos. An electrocardiogram is obtained and shown in the picture. Which of the following has a strong positive correlation with this patient’s heart rhythm?
(A) Digoxin blood level (B) PR interval (C) Age (D) Amiodarone blood level
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and a sensation that her heart was racing for the past 3 days. She adds that she has lost weight over the last 7 weeks, despite a good appetite, and is anxious most of the time with difficulty sleeping at night. She has smoked 10 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years. Her blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg, temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and pulse is irregular with a rate of 140–150/min. On physical examination she is thin, frail, and appears anxious. Her palms are sweaty and there are fine tremors on extension of both hands. She has a palpable smooth thyroid mass. Examination of the eyes reveals bilateral exophthalmos. An electrocardiogram is obtained and shown in the picture. Which of the following has a strong positive correlation with this patient’s heart rhythm?
options: (A) Digoxin blood level (B) PR interval (C) Age (D) Amiodarone blood level
outputs:
The patient has difficulty breathing and a sensation that her heart was racing for the past 3 days. She also mentions that she has lost weight over the last 7 weeks, despite a good appetite, and is anxious most of the time with difficulty sleeping at night. She has smoked 10 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years. Her blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg, temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and pulse is irregular with a rate of 140–150/min. On physical examination, she is thin, frail, and appears anxious. Her palms are sweaty and there are fine tremors on extension of both hands. She has a palpable smooth thyroid mass. Examination of the eyes reveals bilateral exophthalmos. An electrocardiogram is obtained and shows a heart rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation. The patient's history of smoking and anxiety, as well as her physical examination findings, suggest that she may have hyperthyroidism. The patient's age and the presence of exophthalmos also support this diagnosis. The most likely cause of the patient's atrial fibrillation is hyperthyroidism. The answer is (C).

Q: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, fever, and stiff neck 3 hours ago. He has been well recently. He has no significant medical history. He takes no medications. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows Kernig sign and Brudzinski sign are positive. There is no meningism. There is no evidence of a focal neurological deficit. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform lumbar puncture (B) Administer ceftriaxone and cefotaxime (C) Administer vancomycin (D) Administer acetaminophen
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a sudden onset of severe headache, fever, and stiff neck 3 hours ago. He has no significant medical history. He takes no medications. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows Kernig sign and Brudzinski sign are positive. There is no meningism. There is no evidence of a focal neurological deficit. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with meningitis. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a lumbar puncture to confirm the diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 27-year-old male suddenly develops severe abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea. The patient reports consuming undercooked ground beef four days prior to the onset of the symptoms. Which of the following best describes the toxin-mediated mechanism of this disease process?
(A) Depolymerization of actin filaments in gastrointestinal mucosal cells, leading to mucosal cell death (B) Increased pH of gastrointestinal lumen resulting in reduced mucosal absorption (C) Increased intracellular cAMP in gastrointestinal mucosal cells, resulting in decreased absorption and increased secretion in the digestive tract (D) Inhibition of the 60S ribosomal subunit, resulting in decreased protein synthesis in gastrointestinal mucosal cells
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 27-year-old male suddenly develops severe abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea. The patient reports consuming undercooked ground beef four days prior to the onset of the symptoms. Which of the following best describes the toxin-mediated mechanism of this disease process?
options: (A) Depolymerization of actin filaments in gastrointestinal mucosal cells, leading to mucosal cell death (B) Increased pH of gastrointestinal lumen resulting in reduced mucosal absorption (C) Increased intracellular cAMP in gastrointestinal mucosal cells, resulting in decreased absorption and increased secretion in the digestive tract (D) Inhibition of the 60S ribosomal subunit, resulting in decreased protein synthesis in gastrointestinal mucosal cells
outputs:
The patient has severe abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea. The patient reports consuming undercooked ground beef four days prior to the onset of the symptoms. The most likely diagnosis is E. coli O157:H7, which can cause hemorrhagic colitis. The toxin-mediated mechanism of this disease process is the inhibition of the 60S ribosomal subunit, resulting in decreased protein synthesis in gastrointestinal mucosal cells. This is the mechanism of the Shiga toxin produced by E. coli O157:H7. The answer is (D).

Q: A 25-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 4-day history of fever, chills, and a productive cough with rusty sputum. She also reports left-sided chest pain that is worsened by deep breathing and coughing. She has a history of asthma and has been taking her medications as prescribed. She is currently taking prednisone. She appears acutely ill. Her vital signs are: temperature, 38.2°C (100.8°F); pulse, 110/min; respirations, 24/min; blood pressure, 118/76 mm Hg; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. Chest examination shows bilateral expiratory wheezing, and there is a 2-cm area of consolidation in the left lung. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. A chest radiograph shows a left lower lobe infiltrate. A complete blood cell count shows a white blood cell count of 12,000/μL with a normal differential. The patient is admitted to the hospital for further management. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer IV ceftriaxone and metronidazole (B) Administer IV amoxicillin and clavulanate (C) Administer IV cefotaxime and metronidazole (D) Administer IV vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has fever, chills, and a productive cough with rusty sputum. She also reports left-sided chest pain that is worsened by deep breathing and coughing. She has a history of asthma and has been taking her medications as prescribed. She is currently taking prednisone. Chest examination shows bilateral expiratory wheezing, and there is a 2-cm area of consolidation in the left lung. The most likely diagnosis is pneumonia. The patient is admitted to the hospital for further management. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer IV ceftriaxone and metronidazole. Ceftriaxone is effective against common causes of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), including Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. Metronidazole is effective against anaerobes such as Bacteroides fragilis, which can cause CAP. The answer is (A).

Q: A 6-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He has had no diarrhea or constipation. He is afebrile; the blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and the heart rate is 120/min. There is no tenderness to palpation of the abdomen. Urinalysis shows 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The patient appears ill. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer IV ceftriaxone and metronidazole (B) Administer IV amoxicillin and clavulanate (C) Administer IV cefotaxime and metronidazole (D) Administer IV vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He has had no diarrhea or constipation. The patient appears ill

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 46-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with one week of intermittent nausea and vomiting. She does not have any sick contacts, and her medical history is significant only for diabetes well-controlled on metformin. She also complains of some weakness and back/leg pain. She says that she recently returned from traveling abroad and had been administered an antibiotic during her travels for an unknown infection. On presentation, her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 119/78 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 25/min. An EKG is obtained showing flattening of the T wave. After further testing, the physician prescribes a thiazide for this patient. Which of the following diseases is also associated with this patient's most likely diagnosis?
(A) Rheumatoid arthritis (B) Sjogren syndrome (C) Systemic lupus erythematosus (D) Wilson disease
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 46-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with one week of intermittent nausea and vomiting. She does not have any sick contacts, and her medical history is significant only for diabetes well-controlled on metformin. She also complains of some weakness and back/leg pain. She says that she recently returned from traveling abroad and had been administered an antibiotic during her travels for an unknown infection. On presentation, her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 119/78 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 25/min. An EKG is obtained showing flattening of the T wave. After further testing, the physician prescribes a thiazide for this patient. Which of the following diseases is also associated with this patient's most likely diagnosis?
options: (A) Rheumatoid arthritis (B) Sjogren syndrome (C) Systemic lupus erythematosus (D) Wilson disease
outputs:
The patient has nausea and vomiting, weakness, back/leg pain, and flattening of the T wave on EKG. She recently returned from traveling abroad and had been administered an antibiotic during her travels for an unknown infection. The most likely diagnosis is hypomagnesemia. The patient's symptoms of nausea and vomiting, weakness, and back/leg pain are consistent with hypomagnesemia. Hypomagnesemia can cause flattening of the T wave on EKG. The patient's recent antibiotic use increases the likelihood of hypomagnesemia. Thiazides are diuretics that can cause hypomagnesemia by increasing urinary excretion of magnesium. The answer is (A).

Q: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for a 6-month history of worsening dyspnea and fatigue. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He recently discontinued smoking 6 months ago. He appears comfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a grade 2/6 systolic murmur at the left sternal border, a 3/6 diastolic murmur at the apex, and an irregularly irregular rhythm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows a heart rate of 80/min, P-P interval of 120 milliseconds, QRS duration of 120 milliseconds, and a QTc interval of 440 milliseconds. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged heart with a prominent aortic arch. Echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction of 40%, left ventricular end-diastolic dimension of 5.8 cm, and left ventricular end-systolic dimension of 4.2 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Stress echocardiogram (B) Coronary angiography (C) Holter monitor (D) Cardiac MRI
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He recently discontinued smoking 6 months ago. He appears comfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a grade 2/6 systolic murmur at the left sternal border, a 3/6 diastolic murmur at the apex, and an irregularly irregular rhythm. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows a heart rate of 80/min, P-P interval of 120 milliseconds, QRS duration of 120 milliseconds, and a QTc interval of 440 milliseconds. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged heart with a prominent aortic arch. Echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction of 40%, left ventricular end-diastolic dimension of 5.8 cm, and left ventricular end-systolic dimension of 4.2 cm. The patient has symptoms consistent with heart failure and has a positive physical examination and diagnostic tests consistent with heart failure. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a stress echocardiogram to evaluate the patient's exercise capacity and left ventricular function. The answer is (A).
