Q: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son with a fever over the past day. The patient’s son adds that his father has been having some behavioral problems, as well, and that he was complaining about bugs crawling over his skin this morning even though there were no insects. Past medical history is unremarkable. No current medications. The patient was an alcoholic for several years but abruptly quit drinking 5 days ago. The patient’s temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F), pulse is 130/min, blood pressure is 146/88 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical examination, he is confused, restless, agitated, and lacks orientation to time, place or person. Which of the following the most appropriate initial course of treatment of this patient?
(A) Chlorpromazine (B) Clonidine (C) Diazepam (D) Haloperidol
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son with a fever over the past day. The patient’s son adds that his father has been having some behavioral problems, as well, and that he was complaining about bugs crawling over his skin this morning even though there were no insects. Past medical history is unremarkable. No current medications. The patient was an alcoholic for several years but abruptly quit drinking 5 days ago. The patient’s temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F), pulse is 130/min, blood pressure is 146/88 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical examination, he is confused, restless, agitated, and lacks orientation to time, place or person. Which of the following the most appropriate initial course of treatment of this patient?
options: (A) Chlorpromazine (B) Clonidine (C) Diazepam (D) Haloperidol
outputs:
The patient has a fever, behavioral problems, and is confused, restless, agitated, and lacks orientation to time, place, or person. The patient also has a history of alcoholism and recently quit drinking. This could be a case of alcohol withdrawal delirium. The most appropriate initial course of treatment for this patient would be benzodiazepines, such as diazepam, to help manage the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal delirium. The answer is (C).

Q: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of worsening dyspnea, wheezing, and cough. He has a 20-year history of smoking and a 10-year history of hypertension. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 178/108 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a blood pressure cuff size 16 (XL) and a prominent thyromental distance. The trachea is deviated to the right. There is a moderate expiratory wheeze and rhonchi. A chest x-ray shows a prominent right hilar shadow with a suggestion of a mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Asthma (B) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (C) Laryngeal cancer (D) Pneumonia
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-week history of worsening dyspnea, wheezing, and cough. He has a 20-year history of smoking and a 10-year history of hypertension. The physical examination shows a blood pressure cuff size 16 (XL) and a prominent thyromental distance. The trachea is deviated to the right. There is a moderate expiratory wheeze and rhonchi. A chest x-ray shows a prominent right hilar shadow with a suggestion of a mass. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The chest x-ray suggests a possible mass, which could be a lung cancer. The patient's history of smoking increases the likelihood of lung cancer. The answer is (B).

Q: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea and wheezing. She also reports recurrent episodes of bronchitis over the past 3 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. A chest x-ray shows a prominent right hilar shadow with a suggestion of a mass. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The chest x-ray suggests a possible mass, which could be a lung cancer. The patient's history of smoking increases the likelihood of lung cancer. The answer is (B).

Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: Eight weeks after starting a new weight-loss medication, a 43-year-old woman with obesity comes to the physician because of greasy diarrhea, excessive belching, and flatulence. She also complains of progressively worsening night-time vision. She has had no fever, chills, or vomiting. Physical examination shows dry, scaly skin on her extremities and face. Q: A 63-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking comes to the emergency department because of acute onset of severe, substernal pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw. He is diaphoretic, pale, and has a sense of impending doom. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Electrocardiogram shows 1-2 mm of ST elevation in leads V3-V6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous nitroglycerin (B) Administer intravenous furosemide (C) Perform coronary angiography (D) Administer intravenous heparin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He is experiencing acute onset of severe, substernal pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw. He is diaphoretic, pale, and has a sense of impending doom. The patient appears uncomfortable. The electrocardiogram shows 1-2 mm of ST elevation in leads V3-V6. The patient is likely experiencing an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack). The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous heparin. The answer is (D).

Q: A 31-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, and malaise. She has had no vomiting or diarrhea. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has type 1 diabetes mellitus and is experiencing fever, chills, and malaise. She has had no vomiting or diarrhea. Her blood glucose level is 350 mg/dL. The patient is not experiencing any symptoms of hypoglycemia. The patient's urinalysis shows no ketones, protein, or blood. The patient's serum electrolyte levels, BUN, and creatinine levels are within normal limits. The most likely diagnosis is diabetic ketoacidosis. The answer is (A).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. Today’s visit

Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL

A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

question: Q: A 70-year-old man with chronic heart failure presents to the emergency department due to difficulty in breathing. outputs:

Q: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of sudden vision loss in the right eye that occurred 1 hour ago. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). Physical examination shows a decreased visual acuity in the right eye. The visual fields are normal. The left eye shows no abnormalities. The patient's blood glucose level is 420 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria and 2+ blood. The patient's serum creatinine level is 2.1 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer aspirin (B) Administer insulin (C) Administer heparin (D) Perform a lumbar puncture
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden vision loss in the right eye. This could be due to a central retinal artery occlusion. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. The patient's blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg, and her blood glucose level is 420 mg/dL. The patient also has proteinuria and hematuria. The patient's serum creatinine level is 2.1 mg/dL, indicating that her kidneys are not functioning properly. The patient is at high risk of developing renal failure and/or stroke. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer heparin. Heparin is an anticoagulant that can prevent further clot formation and may help to restore vision. The answer is (C).

Q: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling of the legs. He has a history of smoking and has been treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, rales at the lung bases, and pitting edema of the legs. The liver is enlarged 2 cm below the costal margin. There is no organomegaly. Urinalysis shows 2+ proteinuria and 1+ blood. The patient's serum creatinine level is 2.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer furosemide (B) Perform a chest x-ray (C) Perform an electrocardiogram (D) Administer prednisone
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling of the legs. He has a history of smoking and has been treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient's blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and his serum creatinine level is 2.2 mg/dL. These indicate that the patient has chronic kidney disease. The patient also has proteinuria and hematuria. The patient's liver is enlarged 2 cm below the costal margin, indicating that he may have nephrotic syndrome. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a chest x-ray. This will help to determine the cause of the patient's nephrotic syndrome, such as membranous nephropathy or minimal change disease. The answer is (B).

The patient has a history of sickle cell disease and is currently lethargic and pale. He has a fever and night sweats and his spleen is surgically absent. He also has swollen bite marks on his right hand with red streaks extending to his elbow. The most concerning bite would be a spider bite, as certain spiders (such as the black widow or brown recluse) can cause necrotic lesions or severe systemic reactions, which could worsen the patient's condition. The answer is (B).

Q: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of worsening headache, fever, and nausea. She has a history of migraine headaches and has been using over-the-counter medications without relief. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count shows a WBC count of 12,000/mm3, with 80% segmented neutrophils and 18% bands. The platelet count is 150,000/mm3. A noncontrast head CT shows an enlarged pituitary gland. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Migraine (B) Pituitary apoplexy (C) Meningitis (D) Subarachnoid hemorrhage
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of migraine headaches and is currently experiencing a worsening headache, fever, and nausea. Her physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her complete blood count shows a WBC count of 12,000/mm3, with 80% segmented neutrophils and 18% bands. The platelet count is 150,000/mm3. A noncontrast head CT shows an enlarged pituitary gland. The patient's symptoms and lab results are consistent with pituitary apoplexy. Pituitary apoplexy is a medical emergency that requires prompt treatment. The answer is (B).

instring:
The following are multiple choice questions (with answers) about professional medicine.

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing weakness in both legs for 7 days. She also reports a tingling sensation in her legs that is exacerbated by taking a hot shower. She is sexually active with one male partner and does not use condoms. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F). Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength and clonus in both lower extremities. Patellar reflex is 4+ bilaterally and plantar reflex shows an extensor response on both sides. Abdominal reflex is absent. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following findings is most likely to further support the diagnosis in this patient?
(A) Positive antibody response to cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen in the serum (B) Oligodendrocytes that stain positive for polyomavirus proteins on brain biopsy (C) Presence of immunoglobulin bands on cerebrospinal fluid immunofixation (D) Identification of gram-positive cocci in groups on blood culture
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing weakness in both legs for 7 days. She also reports a tingling sensation in her legs that is exacerbated by taking a hot shower. She is sexually active with one male partner and does not use condoms. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F). Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength and clonus in both lower extremities. Patellar reflex is 4+ bilaterally and plantar reflex shows an extensor response on both sides. Abdominal reflex is absent. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following findings is most likely to further support the diagnosis in this patient?
options: (A) Positive antibody response to cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen in the serum (B) Oligodendrocytes that stain positive for polyomavirus proteins on brain biopsy (C) Presence of immunoglobulin bands on cerebrospinal fluid immunofixation (D) Identification of gram-positive cocci in groups on blood culture
outputs:
The patient has weakness in both legs, tingling sensation in her legs, and an abnormal MRI of the brain. The MRI of the brain shows an abnormality in the white matter of the brain, which could be caused by multiple sclerosis. The patient's symptoms and MRI of the brain are consistent with multiple sclerosis. The patient's age and sex also increase her risk of developing multiple sclerosis. The patient's history of sexual activity and lack of condom use increases her risk of developing other neurological diseases, such as syphilis, that could cause similar symptoms. The patient's muscle weakness and abnormal reflexes are consistent with lower motor neuron syndrome, which could be caused by multiple sclerosis. The patient's tingling sensation in her legs could be caused by peripheral neuropathy, which is a common symptom of multiple sclerosis. The patient's history of taking hot showers could also contribute to her symptoms, as heat can exacerbate multiple sclerosis symptoms. The answer is (A).

Q: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He also has had photophobia and phonophobia. He is currently taking amoxicillin for a dental abscess. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). Physical examination shows a very tender swelling over the left frontal and parietal areas of his scalp. There is no evidence of meningism. The patient appears quite uncomfortable. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. A non-contrast head CT scan is obtained and is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Subdural hematoma (B) Epidural abscess (C) Frontal and parietal lobe infarction (D) Meningitis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting, which could be caused by a subdural hematoma. The patient also has photophobia and phonophobia, which are consistent with a subdural hematoma. The patient's tender swelling over the left frontal and parietal areas of his scalp is consistent with a subdural hematoma. The patient's lack of meningism and normal neurological examination also support this diagnosis. The patient's recent use of amoxicillin for a dental abscess increases the likelihood of this diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of sudden-onset severe chest pain. She also reports feeling anxious and having difficulty breathing. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows a respiratory rate of 28/min, blood pressure of 128/80 mm Hg, and a regular heart rate. There is no evidence of cardiac failure. A 12-lead ECG and cardiac enzymes are obtained and are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Acute coronary syndrome (B) Pulmonary embolism (C) Pneumothorax (D) Panic attack
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden-onset severe chest pain, difficulty breathing, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms and physical examination are consistent with a pulmonary embolism. The patient's normal ECG and cardiac enzymes support this diagnosis. The patient's age and sex also increase her risk of developing a pulmonary embolism. The patient's symptoms could also be caused by an acute coronary syndrome, pneumothorax, or panic attack. However, the patient's normal cardiac enzymes and ECG make acute coronary syndrome less likely. The patient's lack of respiratory distress and normal oxygen saturation make pneumothorax less likely. The patient's symptoms and physical examination are not consistent with a panic attack. The answer is (B).

Q: A group of investigators is studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. Which of the following best describes this study design?
(A) Case-control study (B) Case series (C) Retrospective cohort study (D) Randomized controlled trial
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A group of investigators is studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. Which of the following best describes this study design?
options: (A) Case-control study (B) Case series (C) Retrospective cohort study (D) Randomized controlled trial
outputs:
The investigators are studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. This is a case-control study. The case-control study is a type of observational study in which individuals with a particular disease or outcome (cases) and individuals without the disease or outcome (controls) are compared in terms of their exposure to a particular risk factor or set of risk factors. The answer is (A).

Q: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family because they found him confused and lethargic. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. He has been taking medications as prescribed. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's blood glucose level is 420 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 1+ blood. The patient's serum creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Admit the patient for further management of diabetic ketoacidosis (B) Administer intravenous furosemide (C) Administer intravenous dextrose 50% (D) Administer subcutaneous heparin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. He has been taking medications as prescribed. His blood glucose level is 420 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 1+ blood. The patient's serum creatinine level is 1.8 mg/dL. The patient's presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The patient has hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and kidney dysfunction. The most appropriate next step in management would be to admit the patient for further management of diabetic ketoacidosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. His wife found him on the bathroom floor with an empty bottle of medication next to him. He has a history of major depressive disorder. His only medication is nortriptyline. His pulse is 127/min and blood pressure is 90/61 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils and dry skin. The abdomen is distended and there is dullness on percussion in the suprapubic region. An ECG shows tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
(A) Naloxone (B) Cyproheptadine (C) Ammonium chloride (D) Sodium bicarbonate
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. His wife found him on the bathroom floor with an empty bottle of medication next to him. He has a history of major depressive disorder. His only medication is nortriptyline. His pulse is 127/min and blood pressure is 90/61 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils and dry skin. The abdomen is distended and there is dullness on percussion in the suprapubic region. An ECG shows tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
options: (A) Naloxone (B) Cyproheptadine (C) Ammonium chloride (D) Sodium bicarbonate
outputs:
The patient has a history of major depressive disorder and has attempted suicide. His medication, nortriptyline, is a tricyclic antidepressant. The patient's vital signs show tachycardia and low blood pressure. The abdomen is distended and there is dullness on percussion in the suprapubic region. These symptoms are consistent with an overdose of tricyclic antidepressants. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy would be to administer naloxone, a drug that reverses the effects of opioids and can also be used to treat tricyclic antidepressant overdose. The answer is (A).

Q: A 43-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of progressive weakness and fatigue. She also has had weight loss and a decreased appetite. She has a history of hypertension and has been taking lisinopril for the past 2 years. She is currently taking no other medications. Physical examination shows a thin, cachectic woman with a blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg. There is no evidence of heart failure or liver disease. Complete blood cell count shows a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 3,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 120,000/mm3. Serum chemistry studies show a creatinine level of 0.8 mg/dL, a blood urea nitrogen level of 15 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 70 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows no protein or blood. A 24-hour urine protein collection shows 1,300 mg of protein. The patient's lisinopril is discontinued. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Repeat the 24-hour urine protein collection (B) Perform a kidney biopsy (C) Administer intravenous methylprednisolone (D) Prescribe oral prednisone
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and has been taking lisinopril for the past 2 years. She presents with progressive weakness and fatigue, weight loss, and decreased appetite. Her urinalysis shows no protein or blood. Her 24-hour urine protein collection shows 1,300 mg of protein. The patient's lisinopril has been discontinued. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with membranous nephropathy, a kidney disease that can be caused by lisinopril. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a kidney biopsy to confirm the diagnosis of membranous nephropathy. The answer is (B).

Q: A 23-year-old woman presents to the hospital for elective surgery. However, due to an unexpected bleeding event, the physician had to order a blood transfusion to replace the blood lost in the surgery. After this, the patient became irritable and had difficulty breathing, suggesting an allergic reaction, which was immediately treated with epinephrine. This patient is otherwise healthy, and her history does not indicate any health conditions or known allergies. The physician suspects an immunodeficiency disorder that was not previously diagnosed. If serum is taken from this patient to analyze her condition further, which of the following would be expected?
(A) High IgM, low IgA, and IgE (B) Low IgA, normal IgG, and IgM (C) High IgE, normal IgA, and IgG (D) Normal serum immunoglobulin values
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 23-year-old woman presents to the hospital for elective surgery. However, due to an unexpected bleeding event, the physician had to order a blood transfusion to replace the blood lost in the surgery. After this, the patient became irritable and had difficulty breathing, suggesting an allergic reaction, which was immediately treated with epinephrine. This patient is otherwise healthy, and her history does not indicate any health conditions or known allergies. The physician suspects an immunodeficiency disorder that was not previously diagnosed. If serum is taken from this patient to analyze her condition further, which of the following would be expected?
options: (A) High IgM, low IgA, and IgE (B) Low IgA, normal IgG, and IgM (C) High IgE, normal IgA, and IgG (D) Normal serum immunoglobulin values
outputs:
The patient has had an allergic reaction to blood transfusion. This could be due to an immunodeficiency disorder. The patient does not have a history of known allergies. Immunodeficiency disorders are characterized by low levels of immunoglobulins. The patient's serum is expected to show low levels of immunoglobulins. The answer is (B).

Q: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden hearing loss in her left ear and severe vertigo for the past 2 hours. She has a history of hypertension and has been taking lisinopril for the past 5 years. She appears uncomfortable and is holding onto the chair for support. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nystagmus and ataxia. The Weber Class III/IV hearing loss is noted in the left ear. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows proteinuria (300 mg/day). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Meniere disease (B) Acoustic neuroma (C) Labyrinthitis (D) Otosclerosis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden hearing loss in her left ear and severe vertigo for the past 2 hours. She has a history of hypertension and has been taking lisinopril for the past 5 years. She appears uncomfortable and is holding onto the chair for support. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nystagmus and ataxia. The Weber Class III/IV hearing loss is noted in the left ear. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows proteinuria (300 mg/day). The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with Meniere disease. Meniere disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can cause vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the affected ear. The patient's history of hypertension and use of lisinopril increase the likelihood of this diagnosis. The answer is (A).

A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of sudden-onset left knee pain. He has no history of previous knee injuries. He has been able to walk with a cane, but the pain has been worsening. He has no other joint symptoms. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moderate swelling of the left knee, with erythema and warmth of the joint. The knee is tender to palpation, especially over the medial tibial condyle. There is no effusion. The patient has difficulty extending the knee. The patient's serum uric acid level is 7.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (B) Colchicine (C) Corticosteroids (D) Joint aspiration
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden-onset left knee pain, swelling, erythema, and warmth of the joint. The patient has difficulty extending the knee. The patient's serum uric acid level is 7.2 mg/dL. This is consistent with gout. Gout is a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals in the joints. The answer is (D).

Q: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden-onset severe headache, vomiting, and photophobia. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a sudden-onset severe headache, vomiting, and photophobia. She has had similar episodes in the past. She is currently taking oral contraceptives. This is consistent with migraine. The patient's symptoms are consistent with migraine. The answer is (A).
